fields.title: Yoga benefits beyond the mat
fields.content:
Yoga, a time-honored practice encompassing meditation and physical exercises, has witnessed a significant surge in popularity within today's fast-paced society. For numerous individuals, yoga offers a sanctuary from their bustling and demanding lifestyles, irrespective of whether they engage in poses like downward facing dog on a bedroom mat, at an ashram in India, or even amidst the bustling atmosphere of New York City's Times Square. Apart from its mental and physical advantages, yoga extends its positive impact to various aspects of life, including the realm of nutrition and mealtime gatherings.

Types of yoga


Yoga encompasses a diverse range of styles, with Hatha emerging as one of the most widely practiced. Unlike still and meditative forms, Hatha yoga leans towards a more physically engaging approach. It emphasizes pranayamas, which are breath-controlled exercises, and incorporates a sequence of asanas, or yoga postures, culminating in savasana, a period of rest.

During yoga practice, the objective is to push oneself physically while maintaining a sense of balance and avoiding overwhelm. It is at this point of personal limit, known as the "edge," where attention shifts to the breath, fostering a state of acceptance and tranquility within the mind.

A better body image

Engaging in yoga fosters a profound sense of self-awareness, directing your attention towards the present capabilities of your body. It cultivates the development of breath control and mental as well as physical strength. Importantly, yoga transcends concerns about physical appearance.

In yoga studios, mirrors are typically absent, deliberately encouraging individuals to turn their focus inward rather than fixating on external appearances or comparing themselves to others in terms of pose execution. Surveys have indicated that those who regularly practice yoga exhibit heightened body awareness compared to non-practitioners. Moreover, they tend to experience greater satisfaction with their bodies and exhibit reduced self-criticism. Consequently, yoga plays a vital role in the treatment of eating disorders, as well as in programs that aim to foster positive body image and enhance self-esteem.

Becoming a mindful eater

Mindfulness involves directing your attention to the present moment, without passing judgment on yourself or your experiences.

Practicing yoga has been proven to enhance mindfulness, not only during yoga classes but also in various aspects of an individual's life.

Researchers have described mindful eating as the practice of nonjudgmental awareness regarding the physical and emotional sensations linked to eating. To measure mindful eating, they devised a questionnaire based on specific behaviors, including:

  • Eating even when full (disinhibition)
  • Being aware of how food looks, tastes and smells
  • Eating in response to environmental cues, such as the sight or smell of food
  • Eating when sad or stressed (emotional eating)
  • Eating when distracted by other things

The researchers found that people who practiced yoga were more mindful eaters according to their scores. Both years of yoga practice and number of minutes of practice per week were associated with better mindful eating scores. Practicing yoga helps you be more aware how your body feels. This heightened awareness can carry over to mealtime as you savor each bite or sip, and note how food smells, tastes and feels in your mouth.

A boost to weight loss and maintenance

Individuals who engage in both yoga and mindful eating demonstrate a heightened connection with their bodies, exhibiting increased sensitivity to hunger cues and the sensations of fullness.

According to research, individuals who practiced yoga for a minimum of 30 minutes per week consistently over a span of at least four years experienced less weight gain during middle adulthood. Surprisingly, individuals who were initially overweight even managed to shed some pounds. On the whole, those who incorporated yoga into their routine showcased lower body mass indexes (BMIs) in comparison to their counterparts who did not practice yoga. Mindfulness was identified by researchers as a key contributing factor to these outcomes. Embracing mindful eating can foster a healthier and more positive relationship with food and eating habits.

Enhancing fitness

Yoga is renowned for its capacity to alleviate mental and physical tension, including anxiety. However, it also holds the potential to positively influence an individual's exercise capabilities.

A group of sedentary individuals who had no prior experience with yoga were the subjects of a study conducted by researchers. Over a period of eight weeks, these participants engaged in yoga practice at least twice a week, totaling 180 minutes. The results showed notable improvements across various fitness indicators. Specifically, participants exhibited enhanced muscle strength and endurance, increased flexibility, and improved cardio-respiratory fitness levels.

Cardiovascular benefits

Numerous small-scale studies have highlighted the positive impact of yoga on cardiovascular risk factors. For individuals with hypertension, yoga has shown to effectively lower blood pressure, potentially by restoring "baroreceptor sensitivity," which aids in detecting and maintaining balance in blood pressure levels.

Additionally, research has demonstrated that practicing yoga can improve lipid profiles in both healthy individuals and those with diagnosed coronary artery disease. It has also been found to reduce elevated blood sugar levels in individuals with non-insulin dependent diabetes, consequently reducing their reliance on medications. The cardiovascular and stress-relieving benefits of yoga have led to its inclusion in many cardiac rehabilitation programs.

It is important to consult with your doctor before commencing any new exercise program.

Moreover, ongoing research is exploring the potential of yoga in aiding individuals with depression, arthritis, and improving cancer survival rates.

By incorporating yoga into your routine, you can cultivate a sense of calm and mindfulness amidst the demands of daily life. To find registered yoga teachers (RYT) and studios (RYS), The Yoga Alliance can provide valuable resources.

Namaste.


Source: Harvard Health Publishing

Disclaimer:

No content on this site, regardless of date, should ever be used as a substitute for direct medical advice from your doctor or other qualified clinician.

fields.title: Desk yoga: is this the best way to de-stress in the office?
fields.content:
Indiaâs civil service is encouraging staff to incorporate a âY-breakâ into their day. And it isnât the only option for getting fitter at your desk


Name: Desk yoga.

Age: Yoga is at least 5000 years old. Desks are comparative youngsters; theyâre probably medieval.

Appearance: Stretchy.

Youâve been hunched over that screen for hours. Fancy a coffee? No thanks.

Vape down the alleyway? Trip to the vending machine? Therapeutic gossip about Alanâs shirt? No, Iâm going to take my Y-break.

Your what? Iâm taking inspiration from Indiaâs civil service, which is encouraging staff to take a âY-breakâ, incorporating desk yoga into their day to âde-stress, refresh and refocusâ.

What would provide me with relaxation, rejuvenation, and enhanced focus is stepping away from work. Take a moment to close your eyes, take a deep breath, and exhale.

Some may perceive this as another way for competitive office exercisers to showcase their abilities. It can seem as if they already parade around in sweaty Lycra discussing CrossFit, and now they're endorsing crow poses on the photocopier? However, the Y-break protocol is not intended for yoga show-offs. It suggests four sensible and low-key six-minute routines, primarily consisting of seated or standing stretches, twists, and breathing exercises. It's not about showcasing impressive one-legged planks. One of the breathing exercises does involve making a "steady humming sound," though.

Rachel already does that while writing emails, which can be quite irritating. Perhaps both of you could benefit from the "Yoga for Workaholics 2" video, where two colleagues engage in stretches and heel raises together.

On the contrary, it might feel odd to practice yoga while everyone else is diligently working. Are there ways to discreetly exercise while working? Personally, I prefer the traditional approach of "walking around while carrying some papers" to get some steps in without attracting attention. But if you're confined to your desk, you can try leg raises and ankle circles.

What about cardio? Under-the-desk bikes, treadmills, and elliptical trainers are available for purchase, but the simplest way to elevate your heart rate at work is still to choose "reply" instead of "forward" when making a sarcastic comment about your boss's motivational email.

It's certainly more appealing than CrossFit. Do other employers support office arm-waving and alternate nostril breathing? Some companies in the US go even further by paying employees to attend exercise classes or providing on-site workout facilities.

There could be an argument that employer-endorsed health and fitness initiatives are merely focused on maintaining productivity. Are they designed to ensure that our exhausted bodies and spirits remain profitable until we can be replaced by robots? Surely not. Namaste!

Do say: âJoin us for 6am energising flow with the CEO in conference room 3!â

Donât say: âSorry, we canât accommodate your flexible working request, but why not try two minutes of nourishing cat-cow stretches?â

fields.title: How To Practice Doga: Yoga with Dogs
fields.content:
You don't have to limit your quality time with your furry companion to walks and cuddles on the couch. Here's how you can involve your pup in your yoga practice.

Invite your dog to your yoga mat, and your bond will hit a new level. âWhen you practice present-moment awareness, or mindfulness, as you do during yoga, you enhance your relationshipsââ¦âwith humans, plants, and animals,â says Mahny Djahanguiri, founder and director of the human-and-canine yoga brand Dogamahny in London and author of the book Doga: Yoga for You and Your Dog.

Here's how you can practice doga with your pup.

Instead of forcing your dog into it, allow them to join at their own pace. Begin your yoga practice, and as your dog becomes more curious, encourage their participation. For smaller dogs, you can lift them gently in poses like Virabhadrasana I (Warrior Pose I) to add an extra challenge to your practice. If you have a larger dog, you can rest your forehead gently on their back during Balasana (Child's Pose) or fold over them in poses like Camel or Wheel. You can even take inspiration from your dog's natural stretching behavior and follow their lead in poses like Downward Dog and Upward Dog.

fields.title: The Yogic Diet
fields.content:
Yoga encompasses more than just contorting into complex poses. It is a spiritual philosophy and a way of life deeply rooted in the pursuit of holistic well-being. While some practitioners of yoga opt for a vegetarian or vegan diet, others adhere to a more stringent dietary approach that excludes stimulants like caffeine, alcohol, and refined sugar. The primary motivation behind adopting a yogic diet is to foster healing, balance, and inner tranquility.

Although the concept of a yogic diet resonates with many, the perceived restrictiveness often discourages individuals from embracing it fully. To support you in this endeavor, we have compiled a collection of practical tips and strategies to facilitate a seamless transition to a diet that harmonizes with your yoga practice.


What is the yogic diet?

The yogic diet emphasizes the consumption of natural, unprocessed foods that contribute to spiritual, mental, and physical well-being, aligning with the principles of yoga. It is primarily guided by the principles of ahimsa, sattva, and saucha.

  • Ahimsa meaning non-violence, recognizes the interconnectedness of all living beings and promotes a world free from harm. To embody ahimsa, reducing or eliminating the consumption of meat and dairy products is a significant step.
  • Sattva represents a state of equanimity sought through yogic practices. A diet rich in sattvic foods fosters a calm heart and a clear mind. Sattvic foods typically include fresh vegetables, whole grains, legumes, mild healing spices, and mildly sweet fruits and vegetables.
  • Saucha emphasizes purity and cleanliness. Embracing saucha involves maintaining cleanliness in both our external and internal environments. Choosing organic foods, free from chemicals, is one way to promote purity and remove impurities from the body.

How to follow a yogic diet?


Embarking on a yogic diet and staying committed to it can indeed pose challenges. It is advisable to approach it gradually and with patience. Begin by introducing one or two changes and assess their impact on your well-being. Gradually explore and incorporate additional modifications at a pace that feels comfortable for you. It is crucial to prioritize balance and avoid introducing changes that may cause stress or disrupt the equilibrium in your life. Remember, the journey towards a yogic diet is best taken with a mindful and sustainable approach.

  • Eat fresh seasonal foods
    A yogic diet emphasizes the consumption of whole, fresh, and seasonal foods that are organic and locally sourced. Aim to grow your own vegetables, visit farmers' markets, or directly support local farmers. Opt for fresh produce that is in season and avoid processed and packaged items, even if they are organic.
  • Be vegetarian
    For yogis, a plant-based, whole-food diet is essential. The popularity of vegetarianism and veganism has made it easier to find meat-free options when grocery shopping, cooking, and dining out. Nuts, dairy products, leafy greens, and legumes are excellent sources of high-quality protein.
  • Avoid chemicals and stimulants
    Reducing or eliminating chemicals and stimulants aligns with the goals of hatha yoga, which emphasize purifying the physical and energetic bodies. Whenever possible, steer clear of processed foods, artificial sweeteners, caffeine, alcohol, and tobacco to promote a healthier lifestyle and cultivate purity in the body and mind.
  • Eat at regular intervals and allow space between meals
    Except for the first meal of the day, allow at least five hours between your meals to facilitate complete digestion. Eating at regular intervals enhances the taste of your meals and reduces the likelihood of overeating. Consume food when you are genuinely hungry rather than out of stress or boredom.
  • Eat two hours before asana practice or sleep

    To avoid discomfort during asana practice, keep your meals small and light, ensuring you eat at least two hours before your yoga sessions.

  • Make lunch the biggest meal of the day
    According to Ayurvedic theory, the digestive fire is strongest at midday, making lunchtime ideal for consuming the largest meal. Opt for raw vegetables and easily digestible proteins during your midday meal. Incorporate small amounts of healthy fats from sources like nuts, seeds, cold-pressed olive oil, or high-oleic safflower oil.
  • Eat mostly cooked foods at dinner
    Yogic diet recommendations suggest consuming a cooked dinner as it is easier to digest than a raw meal. Cooked vegetables should be the focus of your evening meal. Consider including soothing soups and root vegetables like carrots, sweet potatoes, yams, winter squash, and beets.
  • Emphasize healing herbs and spices
    A yogic diet places emphasis on incorporating healing herbs and spices such as turmeric, cardamom, cinnamon, ginger, fennel, mint, basil, cumin, parsley, cilantro, and black pepper. These spices offer numerous benefits, including aiding digestion, alkalizing the blood, boosting mood, reducing anxiety, and supporting cleansing and healing. Incorporate these herbs and spices into your meals or use them in herbal teas.
  • Eat with mindfulness and a positive attitude
    Your attitude towards food is crucial. Yoga teaches that eating should be an act of love and gratitude, acknowledging that you are receiving sustenance from Mother Earth. Practicing mindful eating helps you avoid mindless munching or overeating and allows you to focus on gratitude. By developing a peaceful mindset around food, you can learn to eat mindfully, control portion sizes, and understand what your body needs for balance and health. Mindful eating can lead to weight loss, a healthier heart, a calm mind, and a longer life.
  • Consider fasting
    Fasting can be incorporated into a yogic diet, but it should be approached with caution. Fasting involves abstaining from food and/or drink for a specific period of time, often for the purpose of cleansing the body, pursuing spiritual goals, or expressing devotion. Different fasting methods have varying requirements, ranging from complete abstinence from all food and liquids to avoiding specific types of food. Fasting is not recommended for individuals with poor digestion or a tendency towards weight gain. Extended periods of fasting can place excessive stress on the
